text:
George Osborne struggles to explain how Northern Powerhouse helped the North East 18:00, 11 Oct 2016 By Jonathan Walker Former Chancellor of the Exchequer George Osborne accused of treating North East region as an 'aside' Share Get daily news by email Andrew Matthews/PA Wire George Osborne 
Former Chancellor George Osborne appeared to concede that the North East was not a key part of his Northern Powerhouse project, when he was challenged to explain what he had done for the region. 
In a revealing answer, he said the region needed “special intervention” and admitted his policy had been focused on cities such as Manchester, Liverpool and Leeds which are relatively close to each other - rather than the relatively remote North East. 
Mr Osborne was speaking to a committee of MPs who are holding an inquiry into his industrial policy, and what the new Government, led by Theresa May , plans to do. 
The former Chancellor lost his job when Mrs May became Prime Minister, to be replaced by Philip Hammond. 
But while in office, he was repeatedly accused of focusing on Manchester and to some extent Leeds while neglecting the North East in his Northern Powerhouse policy. 
Speaking to the Commons Business Committee, he insisted that the Northern Powerhouse policy had continued under the new administration. 
And describing the policy, he said: “In the North you happen to have a series of cities across the Pennines that are geographically close. If you improve the transport links, invested in the science and industry there, you can make the whole bigger than the parts.” Read More Theresa May's new Northern Powerhouse will include the North East 
He added: “It’s understanding that Leeds, Manchester, Hull and Liverpool, and Sheffield, are all geographically close, and we need to make sure there are links up to the North East.” 
But the comments were questioned by the chair of the committee, Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who said it was “very revealing” that Mr Osborne talked about other cities and then mentioned the North East “as an aside”. 
He asked: “What has the Northern Powerhouse done for the North East?” 
In response, the former Chancellor highlighted investment in the Institute for Ageing at Newcastle University, which investigates how healthcare and society generally can adapt to the needs of an ageing population. 
But he added: “There’s an original concept which is the geographical proximity of these northern cities. 
“If you take Manchester - within a 40 mile radius of Manchester there are 10 million people who live. And that is a similar size to London or Tokyo.” 
Referring to the London Underground system, he said: “They are quite close together, so Manchester and Leeds are the same distance as the Central Line in London.” 
He said the North East was part of the Northern Powerhouse, but said there was a need for “some specific interventions for the North East.” 
In the same hearing, Mr Osborne urged Mrs May to get on with making a decision on a third runway for Heathrow Airport. 
And he appeared to suggest he believes that even more airport expansion will be necessary, telling a committee of MPs that the Government needs to build “runways” if it is to deliver on its ambitions to develop new trade links with countries like China in the wake of the Brexit vote. 
The Prime Minister has promised a decision on airport capacity in the South East of England by the end of October, with Gatwick also still in the running for a new runway. Reports suggest an announcement - repeatedly delayed under David Cameron’s administration - may come as early as next week. 
Mr Osborne said: “Our country has collectively over 60 years dragged its heels on airport expansion. At least the Cameron government has set us up for a decision over Heathrow or Gatwick, but we have got to take it as a country.” 
He added: “Governments that are serious about economic productivity improvements need to go ahead and build runways. They can’t claim we are going to be trading with the rest of the world if we don’t have airports that planes can land on.”
